of Burtville, an old mining centre dating back to the early 1900's. Most of this previous mining 
 was in the form of small prospectors developing shallow shafts and underground workings.

text:
Exploration carried out by Sons of Gwalia in the late 1990’s has outlined a resource of 
 210,000 tonnes at 2.5g/t Au (Nugus 2001) at Karridale, 2km south of the Burtville mine. Gold 
 mineralisation is concentrated in shear-related quartz-sericite-sulphide veins in felsic 
 volcanics. Most of the economic mineralisation is in the supergene zone, between 2 and 30 
 metres below the surface. 
 During the current reporting period Crescent Gold has carried out a resource estimation at 
 Boomerang South, at the southern end of the Burtville line of workings. 
 2.0   Location and Access 
 The  Laverton  group  of  tenements  are  located  250km  northeast  of  Kalgoorlie  in  Western 
 Australia, centred on the historic Laverton gold mining area. Access to the project area is by 
 sealed highways from Perth via Kalgoorlie and Leonora.  
 The Burtville and Merolia tenements are located approximately 30 kilometres south east of 
 3.0   Tenure

 exploration and development package in 2002

text:
(Permian to Quaternary in age), particularly adjacent to the Lake Carey salt lake system. 
 The Laverton Tectonic Zone comprises a greenstone belt, which is bounded by the granitoids 
 of the Laverton Dome to the northwest and the Kingella Dome to the southeast and by the

9.text: north-northwest trending Mt Celia and Mt Varden-Burtville fault zones.

11.text: The central portion of the greenstone package consists of a tectonised sequence of acid to

12.text: intermediate volcanic and sedimentary rocks, including banded iron formation (BIF), between

13.text: two corridors of predominantly mafic and ultramafic extrusive and intrusive rocks. The major

14.text: structural feature is the Laverton-Granny Smith Shear, which trends north-south through the

15.text: centre of the greenstone package. The region is structurally complex, with up to five phases

16.text: of folding and faulting disrupting the Archaean stratigraphy.

18.text: Two greenstone sequences have been identified.

20.text: • The Upper Sequence consists of felsic volcanics and volcaniclastics, which are interbedded

21.text: with basalt near the base. Chemical and epiclastic sedimentary units near the top of the

22.text: sequence overlie them. Although chert horizons and BIF are locally abundant, the chemical

23.text: sediments are rare within the lower portion of the sequence. Mafic sills have intruded the

24.text: lower portion, and are hosted by the units of basaltic and felsic volcanics. The mafic sills are

25.text: absent from the clastic sediments in the upper portions.

27.text: • The Lower Sequence is dominated by a series of tholeiitic basalts underlain by basal

28.text: komatiitic, peridotitic and high-Mg basaltic lavas with minor turbiditic and conglomeratic

29.text: sediments. Calc-alkaline intermediate volcanics and minor sediments occur lower in the

30.text: basalt sequences. The Lower Sequence also contains units of BIF and has been intruded by

31.text: dolerite and gabbro sills. The top contact of the Lower Sequence is marked by the onset of

34.text: The Laverton District can be subdivided into three north-south trending litho-tectonic terrains,

35.text: which control the distribution of the stratigraphy.

37.text: • The Western Terrain is dominated by the mafic-ultramafic volcanics of the Lower Sequence,

38.text: and contains the Lancefield, ICR-7, Craiggiemore, Mount Morgans, Jupiter and Euro

39.text: deposits. This includes Apollo's West Laverton tenement block.

41.text: • The Central Terrain comprises calc-alkaline felsic to intermediate volcanics and siliciclastics

42.text: of the Upper Sequence, and includes the Granny Smith, Childe Harold and Sunrise Dam

43.text: deposits. Apollo's Swincer tenement is situated at the northern end of the Central terrain.

44.text: Western parts of Apollo's Lilypond Well tenements are also located within the zone

46.text: • The Eastern Terrain is characterized by the mafic/ultramafic volcanics of the Lower

47.text: Sequence and includes the Keringal, Admiral Hill, Burtville, and Mount Barnicoat deposits.

48.text: Apollo's Barnicoat and Lilypond Well tenements are situated at the margins of the Eastern

49.text: and Central terrains, south west of the Laverton Dome. Burtville and Merolia are situated

50.text: further to the east surrounding a small granitoid plug. The Jasper Hills and Napier Well-Comet

51.text: Well properties are located in a separate greenstone belt further to the east.

53.text: The Mount Weld carbonatite is intruded along the boundary between the Central and Eastern

54.text: Terrains. The terrain boundaries display evidence of both transcurrent and reverse faulting.

55.text: Elongate basins of conglomerate together with syenitic intrusives are localized along the

56.text: flanks of the terrains as at the Wallaby deposit and Apollo's Lilypond Well project. Small

57.text: internal granitoids host gold mineralisation at Granny Smith and Burtville.

text:
north-northwest trending Mt Celia and Mt Varden-Burtville fault zones. 
 The central portion of the greenstone package consists of a tectonised sequence of acid to 
 intermediate volcanic and sedimentary rocks, including banded iron formation (BIF), between 
 two corridors of predominantly mafic and ultramafic extrusive and intrusive rocks. The major 
 structural feature is the Laverton-Granny Smith Shear, which trends north-south through the 
 centre of the greenstone package. The region is structurally complex, with up to five phases 
 of folding and faulting disrupting the Archaean stratigraphy.  
 Two greenstone sequences have been identified. 
 • The Upper Sequence consists of felsic volcanics and volcaniclastics, which are interbedded 
 with basalt near the base. Chemical and epiclastic sedimentary units near the top of the 
 sequence overlie them. Although chert horizons and BIF are locally abundant, the chemical 
 sediments are rare within the lower portion of the sequence. Mafic sills have intruded the 
 lower portion, and are hosted by the units of basaltic and felsic volcanics. The mafic sills are 
 absent from the clastic sediments in the upper portions. 
 • The Lower Sequence is dominated by a series of tholeiitic basalts underlain by basal 
 komatiitic, peridotitic and high-Mg basaltic lavas with minor turbiditic and conglomeratic 
 sediments. Calc-alkaline intermediate volcanics and minor sediments occur lower in the 
 basalt sequences. The Lower Sequence also contains units of BIF and has been intruded by 
 dolerite and gabbro sills. The top contact of the Lower Sequence is marked by the onset of 
 felsic volcanism. 
 The Laverton District can be subdivided into three north-south trending litho-tectonic terrains, 
 which control the distribution of the stratigraphy. 
 • The Western Terrain is dominated by the mafic-ultramafic volcanics of the Lower Sequence, 
 and contains the Lancefield, ICR-7, Craiggiemore, Mount Morgans, Jupiter and Euro 
 deposits. This includes Apollo's West Laverton tenement block. 
 • The Central Terrain comprises calc-alkaline felsic to intermediate volcanics and siliciclastics 
 of the Upper Sequence, and includes the Granny Smith, Childe Harold and Sunrise Dam 
 deposits. Apollo's Swincer tenement is situated at the northern end of the Central terrain. 
 Western parts of Apollo's Lilypond Well tenements are also located within the zone 
 • The Eastern Terrain is characterized by the mafic/ultramafic volcanics of the Lower 
 Sequence and includes the Keringal, Admiral Hill, Burtville, and Mount Barnicoat deposits. 
 Apollo's Barnicoat and Lilypond Well tenements are situated at the margins of the Eastern 
 and Central terrains, south west of the Laverton Dome. Burtville and Merolia are situated 
 further to the east surrounding a small granitoid plug. The Jasper Hills and Napier Well-Comet 
 Well properties are located in a separate greenstone belt further to the east. 
 The Mount Weld carbonatite is intruded along the boundary between the Central and Eastern 
 Terrains. The terrain boundaries display evidence of both transcurrent and reverse faulting. 
 Elongate basins of conglomerate together with syenitic intrusives are localized along the 
 flanks of the terrains as at the Wallaby deposit and Apollo's Lilypond Well project. Small 
 internal granitoids host gold mineralisation at Granny Smith and Burtville.

27.text: Numerous vertical shafts have been worked in the Merolia Project during the early 1900's.

28.text: The most extensive workings are those at Karridale, where between 1900 and 1905, 1628

29.text: tonnes of ore was mined to produce 4882 oz of gold (Gibson 1906). At Karridale, south-west

30.text: trending, flat, north-west dipping, quartz veins have been stoped to at least 70 feet depth.

39.text: Deep weathering has masked any primary wall rock alteration if it were present. Pyrite

40.text: mineralisation is developed in some reefs below the water table. The only significant wallrock

41.text: alteration is in the Karridale workings, where strong silicification and ferruginisation is evident

42.text: for 1-2 m about the footwall of the reef.

text:
The gold mineralisation in the Burtville/Merolia region is hosted by both granite and 
 greenstone lithologies. Within the Merolia Project area the mineralisation is hosted by felsic 
 sedimentary and felsic tuffaceous lithologies. 
 The mineralisation is restricted to narrow quartz reefs and lenses. The reefs and lenses are 
 discontinuous and probably lensoidal both laterally and vertically. They vary in thickness from 
 1 mm to 50 cm, and often can be traced in excess of 100 m along strike. Pinching and 
 swelling of the reefs is common with the better grades being associated with thickening of the 
 reef. These thickened reef sections often extend some distance vertically, resulting in steeply 
 plunging shoots. The reefs are so irregular however, that no general rule on grade and reef 
 type can be made with confidence. The reefs consist of clean, white (sometimes blue-grey) 
 quartz and although relatively narrow, are generally high grade (30-100 g/t Au). In the past 
 the reefs and veins have been extremely simple to mine because of the soft, competent and 
 extensively weathered host rocks. 
 Numerous vertical shafts have been worked in the Merolia Project during the early 1900's. 
 The most extensive workings are those at Karridale, where between 1900 and 1905, 1628 
 tonnes of ore was mined to produce 4882 oz of gold (Gibson 1906). At Karridale, south-west 
 trending, flat, north-west dipping, quartz veins have been stoped to at least 70 feet depth. 
 In many cases, the shafts extend to 40 m below the surface, where excess groundwater, 
 diminishing gold grades, and fresh rock appear to have made mining unprofitable. Some 
 supergene enrichment in gold is evident about the water table in many of the shafts. 
 In many of the smaller and shallower shafts potentially high grade, narrow (<1 m) quartz vein 
 material has been extracted by hand or by use of a crowbar with little or no cross-cut or 
 development work being done. 
 Deep weathering has masked any primary wall rock alteration if it were present. Pyrite 
 mineralisation is developed in some reefs below the water table. The only significant wallrock 
 alteration is in the Karridale workings, where strong silicification and ferruginisation is evident 
 for 1-2 m about the footwall of the reef. 
 See Figure 2 for Regional Geology. 
 7

8.text: even textured, fine-medium grained biotite variety and appears intrusive into the sediments.

text:
The Boomerang South deposit includes a total of 96 holes of which includes 3 RC holes and 
 93  RAB/AC  holes.  The  Boomerang  South    drill  data  was  checked  for  missing  intervals, 
 duplicate holes and missing holes using the acQuire validation software.  
 The Boomerang South deposit is the southern most workings recorded in the Burtville group 
 and splits tenements M38/0008 and M38/0089 
 Historial mining commenced at Burtville group in 1899 and continued intermittently through 
 to 1922, during which time production is recorded as 6 315 tonnes for a recovered grade of 
 80.6 g/t.  During the 1990’s Son Gwalia mined 1.5mt at 1.6 g/t from the Burtville deposit 
 The Karridale underground mine M38/0008 produced gold from historical workings on two 
 irregular quartz veins.  The veins dipped at irregular angles up to 60 degrees to the northwest 
 and are reported to be from a few centimetres up to one metre in width.  All mining ceased at 
 the  water  table  at  a  vertical  depth  of  24m.    Ore  grades  were  reported  to  have  reduced 
 significantly  above  the  depth  of  about  nine  metres  but  are  consistent  to  water  table  and 
 apparently beyond, where significant proportions of pyrite are recorded. 
 The  veins  are  recorded  as  being  conformable  with  the  enclosing  altered  and  foliated 
 greenstone,  with  an  irregular  footwall  siliceous  iron-rich  formation  referred  to  as  ‘jasper’, 
 which occasionally carries gold values.  In the Roscommon and Bonds Finds workings, lesser 
 production came from highly irregular quartz veins, dipping at flat to steep angles, westerly, 
 northerly and to the east.

22.text: Mineralisation dips -70° grid west and strikes N- S.

24.text: Mineralisation envelopes were digitised on screen for each of the 8 sections of drilling across the

25.text: mineralised zones. A nominal 0.5 g/t Au cut-off was applied and digitised using the 3D sofftware

26.text: package.  The  mineralisation  outlines  were  snapped  to  the  3D  positions  of  the    gold  composite

27.text: intercepts  and  extended  to  adjacent  intercepts  down  dip  ending  approximately  10m  to  15m

28.text: beyond the deepest gold intercept depending on the width and robustness of continuity.

text:
Mineralisation dips -70° grid west and strikes N- S.  
 Mineralisation envelopes were digitised on screen for each of the 8 sections of drilling across the 
 mineralised zones. A nominal 0.5 g/t Au cut-off was applied and digitised using the 3D sofftware 
 package.  The  mineralisation  outlines  were  snapped  to  the  3D  positions  of  the    gold  composite 
 intercepts  and  extended  to  adjacent  intercepts  down  dip  ending  approximately  10m  to  15m 
 beyond the deepest gold intercept depending on the width and robustness of continuity.
